ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about engineered biological systems used for various industrial processes. Learned more specifically about microbiology, energetics, kinetics, reactor design, and inactivation.

In this class learned about biological processes used in environmental engineering for water and wastewater management. I learned how microbes are used to clean up wastewater by interacting with substrates in different engineered systems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Peccia is the biggest strength of this class. He is an extremely understanding professor who knows how to make classes more engaging even when most of them are lectures on the board. Only improvement in the class I could see would be to do more practice problems in class.

This class was very well organized and professor Peccia is an engaging lecturer. A strength of the course is that the problem sets and exams were always reasonable and related to the content covered in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely recommend this class. If you are in the ENVE department this is the only class offered on these kinds of topics and Jordan is a great professor.
Yes. It is a very interesting course, especially for environmental engineering majors.
